articles.headline: Revamping, Home Depot Woos Women
articles.snippet: To balance a drop in items sold for big renovations, the company is trying to get women, 50 percent of its customers, excited about more modest makeovers.
articles.abstract: To balance a drop in items sold for big renovations, the company is trying to get women, 50 percent of its customers, excited about more modest makeovers.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the spring, Home Depot hopes to turn a woman’s fancy toward redecorating.

articles.headline: Obama Cautions Embattled Ally Against Violence
articles.snippet: President Obama put Egypt’s embattled leader, Hosni Mubarak, on notice against a bloody crackdown, edging away from a close American ally.
articles.abstract: President Obama put Egypt’s embattled leader, Hosni Mubarak, on notice against a bloody crackdown, edging away from a close American ally.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  President Obama on Friday put Egypt’s embattled leader, Hosni Mubarak, on notice that he should not use his soldiers and the police in a bloody crackdown on the protests in Egypt, edging away from a close American ally whose cities have erupted in protest.

articles.headline: Inquiry Is Missing Bottom Line
articles.snippet: The government’s assessment of the financial crisis could have used less investigation and more analysis, but maybe it’s too soon to expect perspective.
articles.abstract: The government’s assessment of the financial crisis could have used less investigation and more analysis, but maybe it’s too soon to expect perspective.
articles.lead_paragraph: There was something almost comical about the way the Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission released its report on Thursday morning.

articles.headline: Social Security and Welfare Benefits Going Paperless
articles.snippet: Social Security and welfare checks are being replaced by direct deposit and debit cards, which will change some rituals of inner-city life, like using federal benefit checks as collateral.
articles.abstract: Social Security and welfare checks are being replaced by direct deposit and debit cards, which will change some rituals of inner-city life, like using federal benefit checks as collateral.
articles.lead_paragraph: A rooster is crowing, and an alarm clock chimes. “Wake up, wake up, wake up, it’s the first of the month,” the rap song by Bone Thugs-n-Harmony goes. “To get up, get up, get up, so cash your checks and get up.”

articles.headline: Finding Success, Passionate Followers in Tow
articles.snippet: Dimensional Fund Advisors has taken a quirky, exclusive approach that has endeared it to its clients.
articles.abstract: Dimensional Fund Advisors has taken a quirky, exclusive approach that has endeared it to its clients.
articles.lead_paragraph: SANTA MONICA, Calif.

articles.headline: Once Popular, Car Pools Go the Way of Hitchhiking
articles.snippet: The percentage of workers who car-pool has dropped by almost half since 1980, according to data from the Census Bureau, confounding efforts by urban planners.
articles.abstract: The percentage of workers who car-pool has dropped by almost half since 1980, according to data from the Census Bureau, confounding efforts by urban planners.
articles.lead_paragraph: WOODBRIDGE, Va.  Remember the 1970s? Watergate, disco, oil embargoes and, of course, car-pooling. Many big companies organized group rides for their employees, and roughly one in four Americans who drove to work shared a ride with others.
articles.byline: By Sabrina Tavernise and Robert Gebeloff

articles.headline: For Governors, Medicaid Looks Ripe for Slashing
articles.snippet: The relentless growth of Medicaid’s enrollment and the exhaustion of alternatives have made the program an outsize target.
articles.abstract: The relentless growth of Medicaid’s enrollment and the exhaustion of alternatives have made the program an outsize target.
articles.lead_paragraph: Hamstrung by federal prohibitions against lowering Medicaid eligibility, governors from both parties are exercising their remaining options in proposing bone-deep cuts to the program during the fourth consecutive year of brutal economic conditions.

articles.headline: Bet on Gold Nets Paulson $5 Billion
articles.snippet: John A. Paulson made more in 2010 than he did in 2007 when he bet against subprime investments.
articles.abstract: John A. Paulson made more in 2010 than he did in 2007 when he bet against subprime investments.
articles.lead_paragraph: John A. Paulson made $4 billion betting against newfangled mortgage investments. But he made even more betting on an old-fashioned investment: gold.
articles.byline: By Azam Ahmed and Julie Creswell

articles.headline: Egyptians Defiant as Military Does Little to Quash Protests
articles.snippet: As troops and protesters fraternized, Omar Suleiman, Egypt’s military intelligence chief, was sworn in as vice president.
articles.abstract: As troops and protesters fraternized, Omar Suleiman, Egypt’s military intelligence chief, was sworn in as vice president.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO  President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt struggled to maintain a tenuous hold on power on Saturday as the police withdrew from the major cities and the military did nothing to hold back tens of thousands of demonstrators defying a curfew to call for an end to his nearly 30 years of authoritarian rule.

articles.headline: Calling for Restraint, Pentagon Faces Test of Influence With Ally
articles.snippet: The United States military is trying to navigate a peaceful outcome and remain close to an important ally.
articles.abstract: The United States military is trying to navigate a peaceful outcome and remain close to an important ally.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The officer corps of Egypt’s powerful military has been educated at defense colleges in the United States for 30 years. The Egyptian armed forces have about 1,000 American M1A1 Abrams tanks, which the United States allows to be built on Egyptian soil. Egypt permits the American military to stage major operations from its bases, and has always guaranteed the Americans passage through the Suez Canal.

articles.headline: A Bank Crisis Whodunit, With Laughs and Tears
articles.snippet: A new government report on the financial crisis makes for compelling reading, since so little has changed as a result of the debacle.
articles.abstract: A new government report on the financial crisis makes for compelling reading, since so little has changed as a result of the debacle.
articles.lead_paragraph: TRULY startling revelations were few in the voluminous report, published last Thursday by the Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission on the origins of the financial panic. This is hardly a shock, given the flood-the-zone coverage and analysis of the crisis since it erupted four years ago.

articles.headline: Egyptians Wonder What’s Next
articles.snippet: Anxiety remains over what the protests will lead to, and what the arson and looting portend.
articles.abstract: Anxiety remains over what the protests will lead to, and what the arson and looting portend.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO  Liberation Square was liberated Saturday.

articles.headline: Political Blogs Are Ready to Flood Campaign Trail
articles.snippet: Sites like Politico, Talking Points Memo and RealClearPolitics are planning to smother the 2012 campaign trail in a way they could never have imagined four years ago.
articles.abstract: Sites like Politico, Talking Points Memo and RealClearPolitics are planning to smother the 2012 campaign trail in a way they could never have imagined four years ago.
articles.lead_paragraph: MANCHESTER, N.H.  Tim Pawlenty, the former Minnesota governor who is flirting with a bid for president, has none of the usual campaign accoutrements. No tour bus, campaign manager or yard signs. Few Americans, in fact, even know his name.

articles.headline: What’s Broken in Greece? Ask an Entrepreneur
articles.snippet: As one microbrewer sees it, outdated government rules have helped make many Greek companies uncompetitive.
articles.abstract: As one microbrewer sees it, outdated government rules have helped make many Greek companies uncompetitive.
articles.lead_paragraph: KOMOTINI, Greece

articles.headline: Google Finds It Hard to Reinvent Philanthropy
articles.snippet: In 2004, Google promised to transform philanthropy. That goal remains elusive.
articles.abstract: In 2004, Google promised to transform philanthropy. That goal remains elusive.
articles.lead_paragraph: JUST before Google first sold its shares to the public in 2004, Larry Page, one of its founders, excited the nonprofit world with a bold commitment to philanthropy.
articles.byline: By Stephanie Strom and Miguel Helft

articles.headline: Black? White? Asian? More Young Americans Choose All of the Above
articles.snippet: Many young adults of mixed backgrounds are rejecting color lines that have defined Americans for generations.
articles.abstract: Many young adults of mixed backgrounds are rejecting color lines that have defined Americans for generations.
articles.lead_paragraph: COLLEGE PARK, Md.  In another time or place, the game of “What Are You?” that was played one night last fall at the University of Maryland might have been mean, or menacing: Laura Wood’s peers were picking apart her every feature in an effort to guess her race.

articles.headline: Opposition Rallies to ElBaradei as Military Reinforces in Cairo
articles.snippet: Cairo was seized by growing fears of lawlessness and buoyed by euphoria that three decades of President Hosni Mubarak’s rule may be coming to an end.
articles.abstract: Cairo was seized by growing fears of lawlessness and buoyed by euphoria that three decades of President Hosni Mubarak’s rule may be coming to an end.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO  Egypt’s powerful Muslim Brotherhood and the secular opposition banded together Sunday around a prominent government critic to negotiate for forces seeking the fall of President Hosni Mubarak, as the army struggled to hold a capital seized by fears of chaos and buoyed by euphoria that three decades of Mr. Mubarak’s rule may be coming to an end.
articles.byline: By Anthony Shadid and David D. Kirkpatrick

articles.headline: Israel Shaken as Turbulence Rocks an Ally
articles.snippet: Top Israeli officials are closeted in strategy sessions aimed at rethinking their most significant regional relationship.
articles.abstract: Top Israeli officials are closeted in strategy sessions aimed at rethinking their most significant regional relationship.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM  The street revolt in Egypt has thrown the Israeli government and military into turmoil, with top officials closeted in round-the-clock strategy sessions aimed at rethinking their most significant regional relationship.

articles.headline: Unrest in Egypt Unsettles Global Markets
articles.snippet: The instability could hinder oil shipments, raise energy costs and drive equity prices down.
articles.abstract: The instability could hinder oil shipments, raise energy costs and drive equity prices down.
articles.lead_paragraph: On Wall Street, it is what is known as an exogenous event  a sudden political or economic jolt that cannot be predicted or modeled but sends shockwaves rippling through global markets.

articles.headline: Inflation in China May Limit U.S. Trade Deficit
articles.snippet: Inflation is starting to slow China’s export machine as buyers from Western companies balk at higher prices.
articles.abstract: Inflation is starting to slow China’s export machine as buyers from Western companies balk at higher prices.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG  Inflation is starting to slow China’s mighty export machine, as buyers from Western multinational companies balk at higher prices and have cut back their planned spring shipments across the Pacific.

articles.headline: A Mistake to Write Off the Weinsteins
articles.snippet: Harvey Weinstein, a bottom feeder with a knack for resuscitating troubled projects, may actually be back.
articles.abstract: Harvey Weinstein, a bottom feeder with a knack for resuscitating troubled projects, may actually be back.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARK CITY, Utah

articles.headline: A New Model for Film Music
articles.snippet: In an unconventional deal that may promise a revival in film music, the Cutting Edge Group, based in London, effectively bought the musical portion of “The King’s Speech.”
articles.abstract: In an unconventional deal that may promise a revival in film music, the Cutting Edge Group, based in London, effectively bought the musical portion of “The King’s Speech.”
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — “The King’s Speech” collected an impressive 12 Oscar nominations last week. It might have stopped short of a dozen without help from a British entrepreneur who has planted his business at the tricky intersection of film and music.

articles.headline: Protest’s Old Guard Falls In Behind the Young
articles.snippet: Political organizers, many younger than 30, are taking the lead in efforts to topple a regime older than they are.
articles.abstract: Political organizers, many younger than 30, are taking the lead in efforts to topple a regime older than they are.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO  Last Thursday, a small group of Internet-savvy young political organizers gathered in the Cairo home of an associate of Mohamed ElBaradei, the diplomat and Nobel laureate.
articles.byline: By David D. Kirkpatrick and Mona El-Naggar

articles.headline: Losses at Afghan Bank Could Be $900 Million
articles.snippet: Fraud and mismanagement have resulted in enormous losses, heightening concerns about wider repercussions.
articles.abstract: Fraud and mismanagement have resulted in enormous losses, heightening concerns about wider repercussions.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan  Fraud and mismanagement at Afghanistan’s largest bank have resulted in potential losses of as much as $900 million  three times previous estimates  heightening concerns that the bank could collapse and trigger a broad financial panic in Afghanistan, according to American, European and Afghan officials.
articles.byline: By Alissa J. Rubin and James Risen

articles.headline: Define Gender Gap? Look Up Wikipedia’s Contributor List
articles.snippet: Surveys suggest that less than 15 percent of the online encyclopedia’s hundreds of thousands of contributors are female.
articles.abstract: Surveys suggest that less than 15 percent of the online encyclopedia’s hundreds of thousands of contributors are female.
articles.lead_paragraph: In 10 short years, Wikipedia has accomplished some remarkable goals. More than 3.5 million articles in English? Done. More than 250 languages? Sure.

articles.headline: 12 Years On, Tobacco Suit Due in Court
articles.snippet: The lack of attention on a big tobacco lawsuit is seen by some as a sign that a turbulent era of cigarette litigation is ending with little financial damage to the industry.
articles.abstract: The lack of attention on a big tobacco lawsuit is seen by some as a sign that a turbulent era of cigarette litigation is ending with little financial damage to the industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: A big tobacco case is set to start on Monday in St. Louis involving dozens of local hospitals, the nation’s biggest tobacco companies and 12 years’ worth of filings that fill 43 boxes in the city’s towering limestone courthouse.

articles.headline: Mubarak’s Grip on Power Is Shaken
articles.snippet: The new vice president said President Hosni Mubarak authorized him to speak with the opposition, and the army said it would not fire on protesters.
articles.abstract: The new vice president said President Hosni Mubarak authorized him to speak with the opposition, and the army said it would not fire on protesters.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO  The government of Egypt’s authoritarian president, Hosni Mubarak, shook Monday night, as the Egyptian Army declared that it would not use force against protesters demanding his ouster and, in an apparent response, Mr. Mubarak’s most trusted adviser offered to talk with the opposition.
